steps.title: Boil your shallots for 2 minutes and rinse them with cool water.
steps.content: Boil your shallots for 2 minutes and rinse them with cool water. Fill a large saucepan with water and bring the water to a boil. Submerge 4 cups (600 g) of shallots in the boiling water and leave them for 2 minutes to soften up the skins. Then, drain the shallots through a colander and rinse them off with cool water to stop the cooking process. [2] X Research source For reference, you can get 1 cup (150 g) from about 0.35 lb (0.16 kg) of shallots. Feel free to dump out the old water when you’re done. You can also skip this step and just peel them right away—shallots caramelize better when they're sliced.

steps.title: Peel the shallots
steps.content: Peel the shallots to remove all of the skin. Trim away the roots from the end of the plant with a knife. Slide your knife in a vertical line down the surface of the shallot, which helps start the peeling process. Pinch and peel the outer skin away from the shallot. [3] X Research source If you’re roasting your shallots, you don’t have to worry about this.

steps.title: Grease a large skillet with vegetable oil over high heat.
steps.content: Grease a large skillet with vegetable oil over high heat. Pour 3 US tbsp (44 mL) of vegetable oil into a skillet. Double-check that the stovetop is set to high heat so your shallots caramelize efficiently. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Put the peeled shallots in the skillet and cook them for 5 minutes.
steps.content: Put the peeled shallots in the skillet and cook them for 5 minutes. Check that your shallots fit comfortably in the pan, so they can all cook evenly. At this point, move the shallots around in the skillet, keeping a close eye on them as you go. Flip the shallots over periodically, checking to see if they’re golden brown. [5] X Research source Don’t adjust the stovetop temperature at any point while the shallots cook.

steps.title: Drain out the leftover oil from the skillet.
steps.content: Drain out the leftover oil from the skillet. Remove your pan from the stovetop and lean it carefully over the nearest sink. While keeping your shallots in the pan with a spoon or other stirring utensil, pour out any extra oil so you can move onto the next part of the cooking phase. [6] X Research source While your shallots are pretty well cooked, you haven’t had the chance to add any extra flavor yet!

steps.title: Add butter, thyme, and bay leaves and cook the mixture for 5-8 minutes.
steps.content: Add butter, thyme, and bay leaves and cook the mixture for 5-8 minutes. Add 1.8 tbsp (25 g) of butter, 2 bay leaves, and 1 thyme sprig to the skillet. Stir in the ingredients and continue cooking the mixture for 5-8 minutes. Stir continuously so the butter doesn’t burn. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Pour the beef stock into the skillet and cook until the sauce thickens.
steps.content: Pour the beef stock into the skillet and cook until the sauce thickens. Keep the stovetop on high temperature as you stir 2.1 cups (500 mL) of beef stock in with the caramelized shallots. Continue cooking the shallots until the sauce reduces, gets thicker, and has a sticky texture. [8] X Research source It may take several minutes before the sauce reaches your preferred consistency. The amount the sauce reduces will depend on how long you choose to cook the sauce.

steps.title: Transfer the shallots to a separate dish with a slotted spoon.
steps.content: Transfer the shallots to a separate dish with a slotted spoon. Set aside a clean dish covered in a paper towel, which will soak up excess oil and sauce. Scoop up the shallots with a slotted spoon and move them over to the plate, where they’ll be ready to eat! [9] X Research source Cooked shallots are good for 3-5 days in the fridge. This dish makes about 8 servings, which equals ½ cup (75 g) of shallots per person.

steps.title: Set your oven to 425 °F (218 °C).
steps.content: Set your oven to 425 °F (218 °C). Turn on your oven before you start preparing the shallots, so it can start heating up while you prepare the dish. [10] X Research source For reference, about 2.8 cups (456 g) of shallots equal about 1 lb (0.45 kg).

steps.title: Rinse off your shallots with cool water.
steps.content: Rinse off your shallots with cool water. Turn on the tap and place each shallot under the running water. Focus on any dusty or dirty patches along the outer skin. [11] X Research source You’ll be keeping the skin intact instead of peeling it off, so you want your produce to be as clean as possible.

steps.title: Arrange 1 lb (0.45 kg) of shallots along a rimmed baking sheet.
steps.content: Arrange 1 lb (0.45 kg) of shallots along a rimmed baking sheet. Set out a rimmed baking sheet that’s large enough to hold your shallots. Spread them out in the dish in a single layer so they can all roast evenly in the oven. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Roast the shallots for 50 minutes until they get tender and brown.
steps.content: Roast the shallots for 50 minutes until they get tender and brown. Slide the tray into the oven, keeping an eye on the shallots while they cook. To check for tenderness, slide your knife along the surface and cut through the shallot to see if it’s soft and tender. The skin should be golden brown. [13] X Research source If the shallot is still firm, keep it in the oven for a few more minutes.

steps.title: Let the shallots cool before enjoying them.
steps.content: Let the shallots cool before enjoying them. Leave the baking tray in a cool, open area for several minutes. Once the shallots are no longer piping hot, feel free to serve them. [14] X Research source You can also eat the shallots within the skins, as long as you aren’t eating the skins themselves. If you’re using the shallots as an ingredient in a sauce, vinaigrette, or other homemade condiment, be sure to remove the skins before whipping up the finished product. [15] X Research source You can refrigerate your shallots for up to 5 days, or freeze them for up to 1 year. [16] X Research source
